conclusion: Thermal motion of gas molecules is related to temperature.
In an isothermal process, temperature and thermal motion remain constant.
Processes A→B and C→D are isothermal in the Stirling cycle P-V diagram.
Temperature and thermal motion do not change during A→B and C→D.
Transition B to C is isochoric (constant volume).
In an isochoric process, volume remains constant, but pressure and temperature can change.
From B to C, pressure decreases in the P-V diagram.
Decrease in pressure from B to C typically corresponds to a decrease in temperature.
Thermal motion becomes less intense from B to C.
Final answer: Thermal motion becomes less intense during B to C.
